title: First Cues & Micro Alone Time
summary: Blend foundational cues with tiny independence reps so confidence rises evenly.

lessons.title: Sit Anywhere
lessons.objective: Build a default sit with minimal handler motion.
steps: Lure the puppy's nose up and back until their hips fold naturally.
Mark and reward the instant their bum hits the ground.
Fade the lure after three reps by adding only an upward hand signal.
Add tiny distractions—take a step back, wave a free hand—reinforcing quick sits.
supportGuidelines: Coach handlers to reset position instead of repeating the cue.
Remind them to pay only the first sit, not the bounce that follows.
Log surfaces (mat, tile, grass) to keep generalization honest.
lessons.safetyNotes: Skip slippery floors to prevent joint strain.

lessons.title: Target Hand Touch
lessons.objective: Teach puppies to boop a palm for redirection and leash skills.
steps: Present an open palm two inches from the puppy's nose.
When they investigate, mark nose-to-hand contact and reward.
Gradually move your hand to either side, reinforcing swift touches.
Layer in a verbal cue touch once the behavior is predictable.
supportGuidelines: Encourage families to practice before opening doors or greeting guests.
Celebrate any voluntary reorientation on walks by cueing touch and rewarding heavily.
Share how this becomes the emergency recall in busy spaces.
lessons.safetyNotes: Keep nails trimmed to avoid scratches when the puppy targets enthusiastically.

lessons.title: 60-Second Alone Reps
lessons.objective: Normalize short departures with a stuffed chew and predictable script.
steps: Place the puppy behind a gate or inside the crate with the chew already loaded.
Leave the room for 15 seconds while monitoring quietly nearby.
Return before vocalizing escalates, drop a bonus treat, and exit again for 30 seconds.
Build to one minute only if the puppy stays relaxed on previous reps.
supportGuidelines: Note the exact second whining begins so you can set the next departure shorter.
Coach slow exits—no fanfare—paired with breathing cues for humans.
Encourage journaling what time of day alone practice feels easiest.
lessons.safetyNotes: Do not crate immediately after high-arousal play—add a potty break first.

lessons.title: Sound Socialization Mix
lessons.objective: Create calm associations with household noises and city sound clips.
steps: Play a soft household sound (hair dryer recording, traffic) while feeding treats.
Increase volume one notch only if the puppy remains loose and eating.
Toss a scatter of treats away from the speaker so they move while the sound plays.
Finish by turning off the sound, cueing a sit, and paying generously.
supportGuidelines: Send families home with the curated playlist to repeat at mealtimes.
Coach them to stay below the threshold—yawning or freezing means dial it back.
Log which real-life sounds still trigger startle so you can recreate them safely later.
lessons.safetyNotes: Avoid live vacuum practice if the puppy is still unsure—stick to recordings first.
